Dry and heavily extracted, this wine has fruitiness that is fleeting. It's a tough wine, but there is just a touch of juiciness on the finish.
This wine has a lean side that takes away from the bright acidity and fruitiness. With its berry fruit flavors, it should be rich, but lacks a middle.

With light toast aromas, this is a wine that shows vanilla from wood aging more than its fruitiness. There is a barnyard edge to it that brings out rusticity. On the finish, acidity does bring some freshness.
A solid and concentrated wine, with burnt wood, bitter extraction and only a hint of blackberry fruit for the long term.
This dry, darkly tannic wine is all about structure and firmness. It has weight, but the fruit is submerged under the wood and the solid tannins.
With new wood aromas, this is a toast-dominated wine. The burnt character dominates fruit, leaving a bitter taste. It's likely to remain oaky and dry.

No Bordeaux should clock in at 15% alcohol, and this wine shows its power in extracted tannins and licorice flavor. Its acidity helps to mitigate the heat, but the flavor of black plum juice is heavier than the structure.
Should Bordeaux be 14%? Maybe, but not this wine. It is too big, dry, tannin-dominated and heavy. There is way too much extraction, and it shows in the bitter character.

As its 14.5% indicates, this is a particularly rich wine. Maybe too rich, because it is all superripe black fruit without the balance of structure or acidity. Enjoy it as a blockbuster, probably not with food.
A dark-hued wine, the tannins from fruit and wood dominating the fruit and giving a tendency to dry out. It could develop, although the tight structure does not help.
Soft and open fruit, flavors of black currants, rhubarb and fresh acidity. The tannins are light, the wine attractively balanced with a juicy aftertaste.
A soft, fruity wine lacking great depth, but with attractive red berry fruits and light tannins. It is bright, juicy and ready to drink.
An austere, stalky wine, showing its dry tannins and woody black currant flavors. It has a bitter edge to it, with its lean, dry tannins.

Very light, just hinting at tannins, this is an easy, soft wine, the black berry juice fruit flavors the main taste element. The wine has a jammy, smoky character that comes through, but the texture remains dilute.
This wine seems to have superripe fruits that have given it an unbalanced character. It shows acidity and firm tannins but lacks fruit.

Made from organic grapes, this wine offers red fruits and vibrant acidity with only 8% oak give this wine a light character. Its juicy fruitiness is not fully integrated with the tannins, but that should improve over the next year. Drink from 2020.
This is a dry wine, firm with tannins and perhaps missing the fruit element. It has a dry core along with acidity. The future will leave it still on the dry side.

The wine is soft, just juicy and with little in the way of concentration. Barrel-aged for 12 months in one-third new oak, it is attractive and ready to drink now. Vines are planted on limestone and clay above limestone and iron schist subsoil.
This 85% Merlot and 15% Cabernet Sauvignon wine is soft and juicy but without much character. Red fruits and acidity leave little more room for development. Aged 12 months in older oak barrels.
This is a herbal wine with fruit that is firm and austere. It has spice, a touch of wood, berry fruits and dry tannins. It seems on the lean side.
The wine is ripe, yet with a line of green acidity and touches of bell pepper.
Smoky aromas from wood aging show again strongly in the tough wooden plank notes that dominate this wine. It's a shame, because the fruit is there.

Now definitely mature, even drying up, this wine needs to be drunk now. It has developed a dry, tannic character, woody and stalky, although its balance is still there and the aftertaste has some juiciness.
Rich, but edging toward rustic, with its mature leather and berry fruits, topped by dry tannins. It is firm and smoky, in a very old style.
This wine is totally dominated by wood flavors, giving a hard, bitter edge that will need several years to soften, if at all. The fruit is hard to discern.
Perfumed new-wood flavors from a variety of toasts are strong in this wine. Tight tannins mask the fruit and probably always will. Less extraction and more fruit would have been good.

This wine has fruit but it is overwhelmed by the darkly tannic structure. It is concentrated and dense, with signs of extraction giving a hard edge. The Aubert family has been on the Bordeaux Right Bank for two centuries and currently owns six estates. Consulting oenologist is Michel Rolland.
Firm, tannic and hard, this tight wine has a solid core of dry wood. It seems over-extracted with its bitter coffee flavors. Fruit is hard to come by, although there is weight that could develop.

This 100% Merlot from a small experimental vineyard is solid, firm and still young. It has a dense structure of tannins and wood aging, showing bitter coffee flavors and an austere character after 14 months in new French oak. It will likely remain a tough proposition.
With too much smoky toast, this gives a hard, extracted feel with licorice rather than fruit. Tannins are dense and hints of juicy fruitiness only appear in the background.
A minty, modern style of wine that also has too much extraction and wood tannin for its own good. It's hard edged, the fruit losing out in the process.
This wine is marked by dry tannins and is smoky and toasty, with little sign of fruit. While it will soften, it will stay somewhat tough.
Jammy, overripe fruit does not help this wine. Its soft tannins and acidity provide some pleasure, but that clumsy fruit gets in the way.
Firm tannins and overripe fruit dominate this wine. It will not develop well, with those tannins remaining tough.
Overripe, jammy fruit aromas and flavors spoil this wine. It's oddly balanced: soft on the one hand and tough on the other.
This wine's strawberry jam aromas lead to a palate dominated by tannins. It's dry and missing fruit.
This is a ripe, juicy and jammy wine with red plum and soft berry flavors. The name means "Tame the Beast" but the wine is not fully balanced and probably will never be.
This 60% Merlot, 30% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Cabernet Franc blend has ripe red fruits and soft tannins that give a broad feel. It is ready to drink now.
A fresh and fruity wine, with black currant notes, yet somewhat stalky in character. The aftertaste is bright and light.
This is a dark, firm wine, its fruit only showing slowly. The tannins are powerful and dominate the wine. It feels slightly underripe in character.
This lean wine is high on acidity and structure. The fruit seems to be missing, needing more flesh to feel complete.

Spicy and oaky, with aromatic notes of plum, cassis and pepper. The snappy palate offers cherry, currant and plum flavors, while the finish is tight-grained and oaky. Although lean and not terribly deep, what's here is largely satisfying.
The wine is lean for the vintage, tight and with an austere structure. Its tannins and juicy red fruits are in the background. The aftertaste is dry and firm.
The wine has layers of acidity that come from the underripe fruit. It has bell pepper and spice along with red currant fruitiness.
The wine has the lightness of the vintage. It has spice, red-currant fruits and hints of not-quite-ripe grapes. The wine is developing fast and will be ready from 2017.
Heavily dominated by wood aging, this wine should be showing its fruit by now, but isn't. It has bitterness, layers of spice and smoky wood. Only the aftertaste brings some freshness and acidity.
The wine does have fruit, but it is masked by strong burnt tannins from the wood aging. The acidity shows the possibility of red berry fruits appearing later.
A soapy textured wine that misses any focus. There are soft red berry fruits, gentle tannins and some juicy acidity. But it is just dull.
Fine-grained tannins course through this wine. It has good juicy currant fruits along with acidity. It feels lightweight, without great concentration, but is certainly immediately attractive.
An earthy, barnyard wine with soft tannins and red fruits, this is juicy and has plenty of acidity. Drink from 2020.
The wine has very ripe fruit that leaves a jammy character. Merlot sweetness dominates and the wine seems unbalanced maybe the result of recent bottling.
A hard-edged wine, all bitter tannin and dark extraction. It's hard to tell whether the fruit, if any, will struggle through.

The wine seems lean, severe with plenty of tannins but not yet enough fruitiness. There are hints of black currants and definitely plenty of acidity. The dry extraction leaves a wine that's gasping for breath.

Even for the rich 2015 vintage, this is an excessive wine. Made from superripe Merlot with high extraction, it adds dark chocolate flavors to its rich, juicy blackberry jelly fruit, feeling too big and over-the-top.
A light, juicy and soft wine, it is already drinkable. It has red berry fruits, gentle tannins and acidity. A dry aftertaste comes along with fresh fruits. Drink now.
Solid, dark and extracted, this hard-edged wine has too many tannins and not quite enough fruit.
This is a light, fresh and fruity wine, with an attractive red-berry flavor, plus acidity and a soft structure.

A wine that seems to be all tannin, all wood, with only a feel of black currant fruits underneath all this dryness. These flavors suggest high extraction, giving spice, a high toast wood character, all too much for a delicate 2007.

This romantically named estate is owned by Emmanuelle and Bertrand Amart. The wine is an attractive mix of spicy, berry fruit and dry tannins, with a measure of fresh acidity thrown in. There is an intriguing smoky finish.
Densely tannic, this has edgy black currant flavor emerging between a firmly dry structure  packed with dark berry fruits and fresh acidity. This is light in fruit and heavy on tannins.

Under the same ownership as Château Caronne-Saint-Gemme, this, too is in a soft, ripe style, which would benefit from early drinking. It's attractive, lightly toasty and with good black fruits and acidity.

La Tour Carnet is a reliable cru bourgeois; this second wine is correspondingly less impressive. The aromas are muted, and the flavors tend toward earthy notes and sour cherries, with rugged tannins on the finish.

Based in the heart of the Haut-Médoc, this property has produced a wine that shows a dry character, with bitter extraction and too much wood. There are just hints of juicy fruit that will need time to come through. It could well stay dry and firm always.

A separate Cuvée produced from the vineyard of Château Beaumont, this has an earthy aroma, dense and extracted tannins, and still needs to find its balance. If it is to round out, it will need several years, although it could well remain tough.

This is a tough wine, packed more with tannins than fruit. A bitter chocolate character comes from over-extraction of the tannins. The fruit is slow in coming, although there are hints of juiciness. Give it until 2017.
This wine is lean and austere, with extracted tannins that have left no sense of fruit. It will remain hard, although it will be less dry from 2018.

Closed up and firm, the wine is not showing much in the way of expressive fruitiness. It does have a firm structure, but a taste of bitter extract gives hard tannins and smothers the black currant fruit flavors. In time, it will soften. Drink from 2017.
The wine is hard, tough and dense. Its tannins are solid, dominant, extracted and cover any fruit. It is likely to remain dry.
In this light and fruity wine, gentle tannins underlie ripe black currant fruits. It is almost drinkable already, and will age quickly. Drink from 2015.
A lean wine, hard-edged and with austere tannins. It has some berry fruits that are submerged by the tense tannins and acidity. At the end, smoky wood aging flavors dominate.

A black currant-flavored wine, it initially feels light and then broadens to give black currant and spice flavors. The tannins give a very dry character, leaving the fruit to struggle. Not for long-term aging; drink from 2016.
Wood flavors smother the fruit. It has spice, a burnt smokiness and a bitter-chocolate character. The wine does show some juiciness and fresh acidity at the end.
A hard-edged wine, it's very firm and very dry. It is all structure, showing little in the way of fruit potential.

An austere, structured wine, this is dominated by strong wood flavors. It has dark chocolate, bitter tannins with the fruit element submerged. At this stage, it doesn't have the weight to fully integrate fruit and structure.
An austere wine, serious and densely dry. It has some weight and a firm center, with the fruit lagging behind the structure. This is always likely to be tannic.
A thin wine, with tight stalkiness and smoky, dry tannin flavors. It certainly is fresh, the acidity very marked, black currant fruits bedded into the tannins.
This dense and rich wine is dominated by dark-chocolate flavors of excessive extraction and bitterness. The fruit is hard to find in this wine that will probably remain tough.
This tastes lean, the fruit buried deep beneath hard, dry fruit tannins. There is an old style austerity here that demands food. The final juicy acidity does leave a welcome relief.
Lean, soft and soapy in character, this has a dry core and soft tannins, with a lightweight red-berry note. Not for aging.

A smooth, vanilla-flavored wine that shows good black currant flavors. There are soft tannins, some wood notes, but there is also a stalky dryness in the background. The aftertaste leaves wood and dry fruit in equal proportions. Imported by Wine Frog.

From one of two properties in Listrac owned by the Thomas family (the other is Reverdi), this is seriously dark and tannic, with flavors of bitter chocolate extract and wood. It doesn't feel as if it will really soften enough.
The wine is smoky, with black currant-fruits and a core of dry tannins. Those tannins are probably not going anywhere much, so while the fruit and acidity will soften, the wine will always be dry.

Heavy wood aromas lead to a wine that's dominated by burnt wood with only subdued fruit. It's packed with tannins that are tough and extracted, giving a bitter coffee flavor. Although it will soften, the wine will likely keep its dry, tough character.

A wine that tries too hard. The extract is strong, giving some bitterness. And, although the berry fruits are sweet and rich, the tannins edge the fruit with hardness. On the finish, some smokiness enhances the black currant juice, but that astringency just won't go away.

Vineyards in the northern Médoc have produced a wine that while offering some attractive black-currant fruit also has an excess of wood flavors. At this stage, the fruit should be more prominent and the wine possibly will remain toasty and woody.
Quite minty and herbal, but balanced somewhat by cherry, blackberry and vanilla flavors. A medium-weight quaffer with a fresh, cinnamon note to the finish.
There was a generous use of wood aging here and it shows in the wood and toast flavors. The wine has bitter chocolate as well as black-currant fruits suggesting overenthusiastic extraction.

The wine seems to have too much high-toast wood aging for its own good. This wood has masked the fruit and taken much of the richness of the wine. It could soften and broaden although it will probably remain too dry.
This is an obviously wood-aged wine with plenty of toast flavors. This wood aging has flattened the fruit giving a wine that is soft with few tannins. It is ready to drink.
Tight and stalky, this wine has smoky red-berry fruits and a strong layer of acidity. Still young, it will certainly soften, although it is likely to remain light and lean. Drink from 2018.
This stalky, tight wine has a smoky character, lean black-currant fruits and a tough, possibly unripe fruitiness. It is developing fast, drink from 2017.
Too enthusiastic use of wood has left this wine bereft of fruit and unbalanced.
The producer has probably used too much wood for the fruit and density of this wine. The toastiness does not allow any fruit to show through.
This wine is lean and stalky, with firm, dry tannins that don't give much room for fruitiness. It will be ready to drink from 2017.
Considerable toasted wood flavors show from both the aroma and the initial taste. The fruit is lean, without the weight needed for balance. It's likely to remain an austere wine.
Firm and structured, this is a lean and austere wine. It has solid tannins while the juicy acidity and red berry fruits are crisp with hints of green, underripe Cabernet.

This wine is bottled by the local Médoc cooperative, although it comes from a single estate. With firm tannins and a dense structure, it's austere. The stalky black fruits are only just ripe, giving a green pepper character.

Strong wood aromas continue into the palate of this burnt toast and bitter-chocolate-flavored wine. It is extracted and with a bitter edge. The juiciness from the fruit only emerges slowly and tentatively.

Gravel and limestone soils provide two different origins for this wine. That said, burnt wood and smoky tannins are the only tastes at the moment. the wine does have enough weight and potential to soften out, so drink from 2017.
This lean wine lacks fruit to support the dry tannins. That probably comes from the extraction that has also caused some bitterness. It's a hard wine that needs time to soften.
This is dark and firm with a tough, austere character. It has weight, but the bitterness of too-much extraction gives a hard edge. The juiciness at the end doesn't compensate.
This firmly tannic wine has all the structure of 2010 without the fruit. It's a skeleton without flesh, and it will be unlikely to soften in the coming years.
This wine has a barnyard flavor, and its black currant fruit shows a bitter edge. The tannins are firm and dry, likely to soften with age.

An obviously wood-aged wine, this shows a bitter toast character. The fruit is lean, struggling to show through the dark chocolate flavor. It has an austere finish, which is mitigated by its final acidity.
A wine that is lean and angular, austere, the fruit dominated by very dry tannins. It misses weight with the licorice, meaty flavors and a hard-edged structure.
Very light, the fruit is soft, easily attractive but rather muted. Flavors are of spice, black figs and stewed plums, the acidity a factor along with the wood.
A structured wine, full of fresh black berry fruits, red plum skins and fresh acidity. There is a bell pepper element, but the light texture is spiced and rounded with wood.
Bright red fruits dominate this easy-drinking wine. It has some funky tannins, rustic perhaps, that intrude into the otherwise easy fruitiness of the wine.

This wine has too much wood for its own good. By now, this should be softening but it is not. There's not enough room for what could be crisp berry fruit. It might soften, but the bitter wood-aging character suggests not.
This tight and mineral-driven wine is still firmly tannic. That core of dryness is likely to remain even while the black-currant fruit matures. Drink this wine from 2019.
A serious commitment to wood aging has given this wine a dark-chocolate and extracted set of flavors. This masks the wine, which seems almost austere. It will likely remain tough.
This is lean and structured, with some juicy fruit showing through the bright berries, but also around a core of tannins, acidity, bell peppers and a cool aftertaste.
A jammy wine it has ripe red berry fruits, soft tannins and a red plum jelly flavor. It will age quickly, so drink from 2016.
Juicy wine, with very dominant acidity. The flavors are of bright red plums and berries, but the wine lacks depth, skimming the surface of taste.
Hard around the edges, this wine does have some fruit, but this is masked by the bitter chocolate and burnt tannins. Juiciness surfaces in the aftertaste, but almost as an afterthought.
Made by the Pauillac cooperative, this is a pleasant, lightweight wine, a surprise considering the vintage. There are black currant flavors, but the wood element is too dominant for the fruit.

This wine is lean, austere with high acidity that leaves fruit well behind. It is structured and dry, only hinting at black-currant freshness. This third-generation family estate also hosts monthly musical and tasting events and sells fruit, vegetables and honey.

This wine is not balanced, with wood and acidity opposing each other. It has spice, high toast flavors and stalky black currants. Although it could have potential, it is likely to remain tough. The property is unusual-133 acres in one block.

This unbalanced wine is caught between acidity and wood. It is hard to see how well this will develop. Owner Francis Boutemy, an inventor, created the "Bout'mobile" which glides seated pickers along rows as they cut clusters that are dropped directly into a mobile sorting machine.

This is a simple, tank-aged wine, without any pretensions to complexity. But it has full, red fruit and licorice flavors, plus good tannins. For the difficult 2002 vintage, this is a good wine. Imported by William Grant & Sons.
A wine that still shows some youthful tannins, but is maturing well, its freshness subsumed into the red plum and jelly flavors. It is ready to drink now, but should be decanted.

From a vintage known for its readily-approachable wines, this grand cru Saint-Emilion shows surprising structure. Some toasty oak frames delicate black-cherry fruit. Black tea notes on the finish carry more tannins than the fruit can handle in the long run, so catch this one soon before it heads south.

The wine suffers from heavy extraction that has left wood rather than fruit. Somewhere in there, the black-currant fruit and acidity are struggling. It will soften, although that wood will remain a problem.
An oddly balanced wine, showing both light texture and maturity. Spice, beetroot flavors and tense acidity surface, along with a dry aftertaste.
A burnt-toast, spicy aroma is followed by fresh black currant flavors. This is a light wine, but it is balanced, with the wood fitting well into the fruit. Drink now.
Already mature, this is a light, mushroom and spice flavored wine. The fruit is now a part of the secondary flavors, a nutmeg sweetness giving some interest. To be drunk now.
Light and fresh with black currant flavors, this is a simple wine, with attractive, easy fruit, just given weight by tannins and some juicy finishing acidity.

This Bordeaux from Abarbanel is full of black cherry, root, and oak. All in all it's not bad. Some sweet cherry is at the core, and on the edges you'll find a slight leafiness and some sweet supporting oak. Integrated tannins make the finish smooth. --M.S.
This is a lean wine that feels to have only structure and very little fruit. There are dry, dense tannins and a firm texture that will only soften marginally.
Light and fruity, this shows attractive red fruit, ample tannins and acidity. An earthy character to the wine is less pleasant.
When a Bordeaux wine gets into a heavy bottle, it has something to prove. As here, when the wine has way too much wood and lacks fruit. It could balance out, but that is a long shot.

A subsidiary label of Chateau Gruaud Larose, obviously destined for earlier drinking than the grand vin. Supple tannins frame cedar, tobacco and earth notes, while the light frame holds just enough flesh to avoid leanness.

Offers up decent aromas of sour cherries, then folds in leather and earth notes on the palate. This is an easy-to-drink claret for immediate consumption-little tannin, some coffee, tart cherries for balance.
Bright, fresh wine with a light wood touch. The acidity highlights black currant flavors exacerbated by some greenness.
A lean wine, with a core of oak, herb and citrus flavors. Briary blackberry, anise and coffee notes add interest, finishing with a tannic bite. Kosher
This 100% Merlot is firm, dry and structured. Although the fruit is there, it has been submerged by tannins. Give it a few months for the ripe berry flavors to come through. Drink from 2016.

This wine's bright purple fruit tastes as if the fermentation has only just stopped. Jammy red berries are laced with some tannins, and acidity freshens the wine, only spoilt by a slight oxidative edge.
Berry fruits and dense red jelly flavors are the hallmark of this wine. It is full, although edging on stalky, its black berry flavors mixed with acidity and dry tannins.
This soft wine has a smooth texture and little in the way of tannins. That brings out its red fruit, juicy acidity and light spice notes. Ready to drink.
Certainly soft, as befits a pure Merlot wine, with smoky tannins and cranberry fruit juice flavors. There is a coolness to the wine, heightened by the acidity, a product of the vintage.
This structured wine has ripe black fruits followed by red berries. There is a good depth of flavor, the tannins giving the bright fruit weight and a mouthfilling character.

While there are firm tannins, this wine also has plenty of fresh black currant fruits. Acidity and a crisp texture give it a lift and brightness. Drink this 100% Merlot from 2016 when the tannins have softened.

That this wine is all Merlot is the reason both for its jammy richness and its high alcohol. It gives a wine that is out of balance, with pepper, spice and wood dominating the super-ripe black cherry fruits. It's unlikely to age for long.
This juicy wine from 100% Merlot suggests overripe fruit. Hints of beets and red berries are shot through with acidity. Drink this jammy wine soon.
Ripe and jammy, this wine has tannins as well as red-berry flavors. It is unbalanced and seems old-fashioned and hot.

Turns citrusy and tart on the finish, but this is a decent little claret nonetheless. Smells just right, with cedar, vanilla and cherries combining on the nose, then delivers a light, satiny-smooth mouthful of tart berries and vanilla flavor.
IToo much wood aging has masked the potential of the juicy black fruits of this unusual 100% Petit Verdot wine. It does have weight but that wood is overwhelming.

Buying branded Bordeaux can be a risky business. But a few of the Bordeaux négociants make some good value brands that also offer decent quality. This is one of them. From the great 2000 vintage, it is ripe, lively and fresh, but at the same time has some depth of flavor with red fruits, a layer of wood and the acidity that makes red Bordeaux great with rich foods.
This wine is all about dryness, with hard-edged fruit and firm tannins.
The wine, with its dry tannins, is dense while unfocussed. It will remain tannin dominated.
The wine smells of over-ripe fruit and this sensation continues through the palate. The fruit and the tannins don't coincide.
This wine has fresh acidity and attractive black currant fruit flavors. They are given a hard ride by the dark and bitter tannins and dry texture. This is a Carreau family wine.

Vanilla and caramel flavors dominate this wine after 12 months in French oak. That means that the fruit is really not allowed to shine. It is firm, very dry and all about spice. A pepper flavor from the alcohol leaves a burn in the mouth.
The over-exuberance of wood aging spoils this wine. With strong spice and equally tannic elements, it's all about the skeleton and not about the flesh of the fruit.

The wine is ripe and soft with a body of tannin that sits uneasily within this jammy character. The blend (Merlot 75%, Cabernet Franc 25%, Malbec 5%) was aged 30% in barrel and 70% in stainless steel tanks. It is unbalanced and likely to remain so.
Juicy and spicy flavors give a wine that layers fruit and ginger. Blackberries are the dominant fruit while the spice adds a bite that is almost exotic.
This soapy, unfocused wine has tannins and red berry fruit but little structure. The fruit shows a green streak that will not improve.
The fruity, perfumed character shows instant red berry aromas, but the old-wood flavor doesn't quite chime with the fruit, giving a slightly muddled feel to the wine.
Mint aromas speak of the wood used in aging this wine. With some burnt tannin character, it's perhaps not a wine that will show great fruit.
Earthy aromas are an off-putting start to this heavily tannic wine. It tastes bitter and extracted, the fruit worked too hard during fermentation.
Very dry and hard, with lean black currant fruits. This is likely to remain a tough and extracted wine.
This wine has an unusual candy-flavored character. Its tannins are fine, and there is structure, but the final character is unbalanced.
A firm and tannic wine, with a hard-edge feel to it. The structure is dry and tough, leaving little room for the fruit, even in the future.
This wine has meaty aromas that lead into a bacon flavors. It has ample tannins but hardly any fruit.
Dark chocolate and spice dominate this tough wine. The structure and extraction have smothered the fruit. Aging will be a hard call.
This soft, lightly tannic wine suggests red berries and a touch of spice. The wine is open and ready to drink.
This shipper's blend is plump yet structured, boasting an herbal lattice of flavors draped over a base of black cherry and berry. Modest tannins and firm acidity provide grip to the finish
There are aromas of ripe, juicy fruit. To taste, the wine is soft, juicy, and easy, perhaps slightly dilute. A very approachable wine, but in the end lightweight.
This is a dry wine, more about structure than fruit. The tannins and the firm extraction shows strongly. It is not enjoyable.
This is a wine that has been spoiled by the over-use of wood aging. The fruit is still struggling to come through. It will be a tough call as to which wins.
Light and unfocused, this simple wine has fruit but misses out on structure and much interest.
It is a tough wine with too much wood for the fruit. Wood aromas show strongly in the taste as well. Some balance will come, but probably not enough.
The wine is dry, firm and initially tough. With its dry wood core, the fruit is not getting a chance.
This fresh wine has plenty of acidity as well as some firm tannins. It is still young, waiting to fill out with riper fruit flavors. The aftertaste just repeats the acidity.

Tannins mask the light fruitiness in this blend of 45% Merlot, 45% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Cabernet Franc. It seems extracted, with the producer attempting to get too much out of the fruit in a lean year.
This 60% Merlot and 40% Cabernet Franc blend is very fruity and fresh, balancing dry tannins and attractive red fruit flavors. It is light, still tight with its structure. Drink from 2016.

A light and fruity wine that is ready to drink. From the heart of the Entre-deux-Mers region, it has red berry fruits and juicy acidity. A greener, herbal character in the background suggests grapes that weren't totally ripe at harvest.
This is a thin wine with way too much acidity for the fruit. The rest of the wine is dry tannin that could soften into a more juicy character. It's always going to be a light wine.
Herbal aromas give a crisp character. The fruit is not entirely ripe, so the wine relies on its tannins and acidity to get balance.
This is a structured wine, with too many tannins from wood and fruit. The red berry fruits are likely always to remain second to the structure.
This is a lean wine that seems to be missing the fruit. It has an austere quality with a strongly tannic element and mineral acidity.
Ripe and juicy, this smooth, simple wine is ready to drink. Juicy black currant fruits are polished by the wood aging.
A juicy wine, it has soft tannins and gently stalky fruit textures. Black currant fruits accompany fresh, tangy acidity. Not for aging, so drink now.
This wine seems rather unfocused with indistinct tannins and fruit. There is a soapy texture, and the red berry fruits seem awash with acidity.
There is way too much acidity here, and it's exagerrated by the wine's soft, unfocused texture. Notes of bitter toast and dark tannins are rather unbalanced.
Dry, firmly structured and tough, this is an austere wine that doesn't hold out much hope for improvement. Drink it soon with rich food to balance out its dense tannins and wood flavors.
Very young, fruity wine. The tannins are already soft and there is stalky black currant acidity that gives the wine a bright freshness. It has no wood and will develop fast.
Dry and tannic initially, the wine opens up to reveal a soft, fruity character. It is still compact, with some bitterness from overextraction.
This lightweight wine is dominated by juicy red fruit. Fresh in character, it has bright acids and soft tannins. Not a wine for aging.
This perfumed wine is tough on the palate. It has a firm, dry core, surrounded by red-currant-driven acidity. The finish is out of balance.
This is a dense, wood- and tannin-laden wine. It's hard, with a dry and unyielding structure. In one year, it should be more generous.
This has a tight, severe character, with black currant fruit and a touch of green bell pepper. It's stalky and structured, with a lean feeling.
A tight wine-this is on the lean side, but shows an attractive red-currant flavor and soft tannins. This is not meant for aging.
Taut, stalky wine, very structured. There is fruit but it is herbal, green, missing ripeness. The tannins have the same character.
Very soft wine, with gentle berry fruit flavors, cinnamon and a light, ripe character. Black currant fruits emerge from the light texture with an attractive tannic layer.
This soft, wood- and blackberry-flavored wine shows spice alongside acidity. It has an edge of astringency and green herbs, but the vanilla from the wood does give it some weight and balance.
Lean, initially bitter, this is a firmly tannic wine. The berry fruits show freshness, but the dry tannins dominate. Of course, it's young, but the texture is too light for much development.
A stalky Bordeaux from a vineyard north of Saint-Emilion. The fruit is austere and lean, with plenty of acidity. There are light tannins, and there is fresh fruit, but the core is missing.
Vanilla aromas and fresh red currant fruit flavors give this wine a freshness as well as a simple, easy structure. The acidity could be less dominant.
There is a Rosé here struggling to get out. This wine has strawberry fruits combined with tannins in a way that does not work. Bordeaux Clairet lies between Rosé and red in color and in taste.
Closed and tough, this wine has spent too long in wood. It offers little but spice and toast.
High-toast flavors still dominate this wine, although they should by now have melded into the fruit. It suggests the wine will continue to have strong, bitter wood flavors.
This wine is spoiled by overripe fruit. It has a juicy component as well as firm tannins, but that high-alcohol jammy character is not pleasant.
lean, austere wine, that has dry tannins and flavors of stalky currants. It is pleasant enough, with some freshness, but there is a definite green element to it.
This tough wine has overripe fruit. There are tough extracted tannins. It's a hard wine to like.
The wine has a southern character with very ripe fruit that seems unbalanced for the tannins and acidity. It's an odd wine.
The wine is tight and perhaps firm. Its extracted tannins and dry core are too much for the fruit.
Smoky aromas lead to a wine that is dominated by wood. It is about structure rather than fruit.
The wine is dominated by extracted wood flavors. It is likely to soften, but not enough to allow the fruit to sing.
The wine is smoky and toasty. It is extracted with bitter coffee flavors that dominate the fruit. Too much burnt wood will leave little room for fruitiness.
This wine is soft, full in the mouth while not having much focus.
Toast aromas precede layers of wood flavors that give the wine a tough, dry, spicy character that masks the fruit.
With soft tannins and fresh fruits, this light, crisp wine has a red fruit-flavored character that is intense in its acidity. Drink now.
There is probably too much wood aging in this wine. It's still young, but the dominant toastiness gives a burnt character. It has a hard edge, tough and very dry.
This is hard and tough, all tannins and extraction.
This tough wine seems light on fruit. It is hard and shows considerable extraction.
With a high proportion of Cabernet in the blend, this holds tough tannins. There is also juicy Merlot that offers an attractive, fruity future.
The fruit is extremely extracted, making for a wine that is tough, very firm and hard without the juicy character needed to see it through.
This is a hard-edged wine with a chemical character. It's tough both in tannins and extracted fruits.
Bread and yeasty aromas lead to a wine that has tannins and wood aging, leaving the fruitiness behind.

Bitter extraction hinders this wine. It does have some attractive fruitiness in the background, but it's lost amidst all the toughness. The rigid edge will soften, although the wine's fruitiness may well never materialize.
This wine is too toasty for its own good. It has dark tannins, high spice and bitter toastiness. There is a soapy aftertaste that only just hints at fruit.
Juicy and fruity, this wine has strong layers of acidity and extracted tannins. It has a hard, austere character that doesn't promise for the future.
This dark, extracted wine is firm in character. It has bitter coffee and licorice flavors, which rather elbow aside the fruit.
A hard and tannic wine, with too much dryness for pleasure. It's not likely to soften enough to balance out.
Hard and extracted, this wine shows little more than tannins. The fruitiness is hard to discern and may never come through.
This is all fruit and no structure. The fruit shows a superripe character, which suggests this is a wine for short-term aging.
This warm wine is reminiscent of vintage Port. It is sweet, with dominating nut and superripe fruit flavors. It's soft and gently flabby.
Juicy and fruity, this has ripeness without much structure. This is for early drinking.
This is a lightweight wine with fruit that tastes overripe. It has a soft, fruity texture, and its gentle tannins are touched by acidity.
Attractively made, but uncomplicated wine, with fresh raspberries, acidity, a light tannic coating, maybe spoilt by a rustic edge. Drink now.
The wine suffers from over-ripe fruit that give it a red-jelly flavor. The tannins and acidity make an odd contrast.

Strong wood flavors have smothered the fruit, leaving vanilla, spice and milk chocolate as the main flavors. Gérard Laurent blends 65% Cabernet Franc and 35% Malbec from biodynamic and organic vineyards in egg-shaped Apollo flexitanks where the wine matures for a year.
Heavy toast aromas follow through to a wine that is packed with new wood and some fruit. It has a biting burnt edge that may soften.
A confected wine that shows polished wood and mint flavors but little fruit. It puts on a great show, but without depth.
Lean and tough, this is all hard edges. The wine has an austere character that's likely to be off-putting even in the future.

Simple, light and leafy. Not a lot of oomph here. Some light, dry raspberry fruit and plenty of wood on the palate and finish. You gotta love your oak to really enjoy this one. It's kind of closed, and I wouldn't bet much on its future.
This dark wine has extracted tannins and dark-coffee flavors. Its hard edge is probably not going to soften enough.

This lean wine, all acidity and tannins, has a severe character that is not likely to go away. The estate has been handed down from mother to daughter for seven generations and now owned by enologist Marie Laure Latorre. It was named for the Merlot plot planted on 08/11/99, the date of the last total solar eclipse seen in France.

There is a strongly rustic character to this wine. The fruit seems to have disappeared. and the wine is tough right through. Maceration took place in traditional concrete vats; malolactic fermentation and aging in barrels, 25% new oak.

With no added sulfites and from organically grown grapes, this bottling ventures into natural wine territory. However, it suffers from a tinny character that can affect these wines and shows some hints of volatility. The second bottle tasted was less volatile.
Soft, ripe and jammy, this is too ripe and misses structure. Its acidity does redeem it, but it is not going to develop much.
This is a spicy wine, soft and open. Its tannins and red berry fruits have a diffuse character that takes away the focus of the wine. It will age quickly.
Very dry and with too much wood, this is an attenuated wine with a hard facade. It doesn't offer enough fruit for the future.
This wine veers between firm tannins from old wood and red fruit acidity, without finding balance. It's very dry, with a hard edge.

A lean, somewhat austere wine that emphasizes tight tannins and minerality. The fruit is firm, but at the same time both slightly oxidized and edging towards green. The result is a set of flavors that definitely demands food.
While this wine shows some of the softness and richness of 2003, it keeps a light touch and the acidity and black fruits remain fresh. There is an edge of astringency that leaves a hard aftertaste.
This wine is all structure and dark, dry tannins. The fruit is very subdued, giving a hard wine that could well remain tough.
A very juicy wine that shows overripe fruit and an herbal character. It's soft, fruity without great definition and likely to develop quickly.
Juicy but not quite ripe, this is a green and herbal wine that is not worth aging. Drink it over the next few years.
With barnyard aromas, this is a rustic wine. It does have some red fruit flavors and acidity but these are compromised by the earthy texture.
This wine is fruity but has a lean texture that emphasizes tannins rather than fruit. With a dry core and bitter-chocolate flavors, the wine misses out on the fruit.

Spicy, foresty aromas dominate what subdued fruit there is. The palate is tight and grippy, with full-on tannins that really get after your cheeks. Amid those tannins is some grapey fruit and a bit of toastiness.
Starts off with an herbal note that carries throughout. Blackberry, cassis, tar, spice and citrus flavors are in evidence as well. Tannins are a bit rustic. Kosher
Lean and tannic, this wine has chocolate and bitter coffee flavors from over-extraction. The fruit is suppressed at this stage, with a bitter aftertaste.
The wine is stalky with a green element that suggests underripe fruit. Black currant competes with burnt flavors that will soften as the wine ages. Drink from 2017.
Earthy aromas need time to blow away once this is opened. After that, the wine gives lean fruit, a tight and mineral stalkiness and high acidity. Bitter extraction cuts through the wine.
This is a special selection from parcels of vines in Château Castéra. Stewed plum aromas lead to a wine that is lean, leaving little room for the fruit.
A rather soapy, wine, it does not have enough fruitiness to sustain its tannins. It's hard edged and likely to remain that way.
Dry and light, an unfocused wine. It has tannins, only light fruit, very dry and ultimately tough.
Shows its Right Bank roots in Merlot and Cab Franc-derived red fruit and herb flavors: strawberry, tomato and rhubarb. Turns leathery and earthy, with some hints of toast on the finish.
A thin wine that is all dry tannins and not enough fruit. It is lightweight with just a hint of juiciness.
Definitely on a downward slope, this wine is very dry, the fruit gone and replaced by tannins. Drink now. Imported
This has plenty of tannins, but seems thin on the fruit. It gives an unbalanced wine that should have filled out by now. The texture is extracted with a hard edge.
A very dry, tannic wine, full of dense structure. The fruit can be found underneath all this dryness, a layer of hedgerow blackberries, tight and firm. At the end, there is some baked acidity.
A hard, too-toasty wine that is completely dominated by smoky wood flavors. Whatever fruit is there is swamped, only a juicy hint through the wine's weight.

Lean and earthy, but clean, and with an appealing freshness. Cherry and berry fruit dominates, and the finish is true. And there's even some patented Bordeaux herbaceousness, but in a good way. Kosher.

This Kosher Bordeaux has woody, maple-like aromas along with some smoky, rubbery accents. The palate offers some cherry and cola flavors, while the finish is smooth enough, with pronounced woody notes.
This is a light 100% Merlot wine, with tangy red berry fruits. Tight and mineral with high levels of acidity, it is not for aging, so drink now.
Overripe fruit from a small experimental vineyard is the hallmark of this wine. The awkwardness is not helped by the extracted tannins.

Aromas of maple, black pepper and cherry cough drop get it going in a fair to midland direction. The palate is basic, with only some standard berry fruit and oak, while the finish is lengthy and easy, but also kind of mute. In terms of mouthfeel, some hard tannins prevent it from falling into the "friendly" category.
This wine has too much tannin for its own good. It's tough and bitter, showing wood and extraction. In this difficult Bordeaux vintage, the vineyard produced less than half what is normal.
The wine is all toast and smoky wood flavors though it spent only six to eight months in oak. It is extracted and hard, with little fruit.

Overripe, jammy fruits and dry tannins are an odd combination. They don't work in this wine that has a hot character. This is the first vineyard in Blaye certified by Terra Vitis for sustainable viticulture.
A diffuse wine without focus. The tannins and the fruit are some way apart, while the final flavor is dry and tough.
Bell peppers and green herbs as well as dark tannins are the main characters of this very dry, bitter wine.
This unfocused wine has hard tannins and a firm structure. What's missing is the fruit, which may not come through.

I know Bordeaux isn't known for being fruit-driven, but this paucity of fruit in a wine that's 50% Merlot (from a vintage that favored this variety's development) is hard to fathom. Leather and old wood combine with earth and mushrooms. There's decent weight and intensity here, so if these are flavors you look for this is an example to seek out.
The wine is dry, laden with wood flavors rather than fruit. It has a hard over-extracted edge that will stay with the wine as it ages.
This is an unfocused wine with fruit flavors that miss the mark. Only the juicy aftertaste is attractive.
This is a tight woody wine that is hard and over-extracted. Some fruit may come through but it is hard to imagine.
You need to work hard to find the fruit in this 100% Merlot. It is tough, only hinting at acidity and black currant flavors.
Dry tannins and wood flavors give a hard character. It's tough to see beyond the wine's dryness and find the fruit.
Crisp fruitiness and acidity show the fruit is not ripe. It's a herbal and stalky.

While this wine is still young, the level of smoky wood aging flavors is enormous. It's all about planks and not about fruit, not taking into account the light vintage. Could the black fruits develop? Certainly, but maybe not enough.
This is a wine that is totally dominated by wood. So much so that there is little sign of fruit. Maybe it will integrate, but there is a question mark.
Overripe fruit makes this wine, which is light and fruity, with little structure.
This firm, dry wine is all tannins and bitter extraction. It has a hard side to it that the juicy fruit cannot balance.
Fruity and without structure, this wine is soft and feels rather dilute. The red fruits dominate and will age quickly. Screwcap.
Dry, dark-hued tannins cut through the wine, giving it a bitter feel. It is tough, firm, missing the balancing fruit.
Indulgent wood and high toast flavors swamp the fruit here. The result is a wine that is lean, hard-edged and without the weight to develop.
A simple, fruity wine, the fruit on the lean side, with black currant flavors and fresh berry acidity. There is an unfortunate rustic edge to the tannins.

A tight, firmly tannic wine. It does show pleasing berry fruits, and it has freshness, but the acidity is very apparent, and courses through the fruit and tannins. The finish is tart black currant. Screwcap.
A raw-edged wine, with dusty tannins and blackberry fruits and sawdust wood flavors that don't quite gel, and some green asparagus flavors to finish.
The toffee aromas of this wine are followed by an unbalanced character of Clairet on the palate. Dry and not very fruity now, it will probably remain like this.
The acidity that is a characteristic of the vintage shows through in this wine. It clashes with the tannins to give a strangely unbalanced wine.
High levels of acidity give this wine a tight, eye-watering character. The fruit was probably not ripe.
This wine is dry, firm with chocolate and bitter extraction flavors. It's likely to remain dry.
Hard and extracted, this is a tough number. The fruit seems lean and the bitter chocolate flavor is not promising much. It may work with food.
The unfocused wine tastes soapy, with bitterness and little fruit. Not a wine to enjoy now or in the future.
There is an awkwardness to this wine, coming from the overripe fruit and juicy character. It lacks structure and will likely age quickly.
A meat-flavored wine without much charm, this has tannins and red berry notes, along with a strong whiff of sulfur.
This is bizarrely perfumed: It tastes like a candy shop smells, with a note of fruit jelly. The tannins are taut, but the wine doesn't hang together.
On the lean side, this wine has an intense black-currant flavor and acidity, producing a wine that tastes mean and is not likely to age.
The fruit seems overripe, with a juicy character. A core of tannins balances the palate, and a meaty flavor creeps in on the finish.
Heavily wooded wine, so dry, with the fruit lost in all the burnt toast character. It's all too much for the fresh style of 2008.
A Merlot-dominated wine, soft, fresh, the tannins a whisper under red berry fruits. This simple freshness is spoilt by a dirty edge to the acidity, giving a final bitterness.
A lean wine with some austerity. It has a firmly tannic character while missing the fruit for the future.

This old-vine wine shows signs of rotten fruit, certainly aromatically. On the palate, it is tight with dark tannins and a hard, extracted edge. It is hard to tell if it could soften. This property liess in both the Castillon and Franc appellations. Wine is vinified plot by plot.
This wine has a jammy character with acidity that is unbalanced. Wine is made in cement tanks and aged in cement tanks and new and up to three-year-old French oak barrels.

The new wood and spice flavors still show in this wine. A dry, woody character is still keeping the fruit back. Black coffee flavors show that there was heavy extraction. This 20-acre property is one of four in the greater Saint-Émilion area owned by the Lannoye family.
A lean and underweight wine. It has some juicy fruit but it misses depth of flavor.
Rustic, barnyard aromas with flavors of hedgerow red berries and light acidity. The style is fruity; the sweet fruits are shot through with some licorice and beetroot flavors.
An over-oaked wine. The lean 2007 fruit cannot cope with the wood, resulting in a wine that is one-dimensional.
All tannin, this wine is missing fruit, although the acidity hints at some fading freshness. It is tough and dry, not offering much real pleasure.
Mature Bordeaux from a not very good vintage. It is drying up, the flesh gone, just the bare bones of tannin remaining.

Olive and pickle notes run on top of the fruit on the nose, while more olive character along with coffee and black fruit carry the palate. Vibrancy is not this wine's calling card; it's more dark, earthy and ultimately kind of flat.
Red cherry aromas lead to a wine that is curiously structured with firm tannins and jammy fruit that is not in balance. "Natur" means the winemaker did not add sulfites during wine production.
Aromas and flavors of rhubarb and red pepper dominate, resulting in a wine that is sharp and unbalanced.
This is very light, in both flavor and body. The aromas are earthy, with a faint suggestion of blackberries, and the mouthfeel is thin. These aren't terrible flaws, but the wine just lacks substance.
This is very light, in both flavor and body. The aromas are earthy, with a faint suggestion of blackberries, and the mouthfeel is thin. These aren't terrible flaws, but the wine just lacks substance.

This wine has been too heavily extracted, giving a series of tough tannins and a hard edge without the fruit to balance things out. It is a blend of 50% Cabernet Sauvignon and 25/25 Merlot and Cabernet Franc.
Meat and bacon aromas lead to a dry, tannic wine. It only hints at a fruity future.
This is an unfocused wine that has jammy fruit and soft tannins. It tastes overripe. Not for aging.
Meat and bacon aromas introduce a wine that is taut, structured and high on the acidity. It has a lean, slightly dirty taste, which is not attractive.
A lean, rather attenuated wine. It has some pleasant red fruits, but is too dilute. Drink now, while the fruit is still fresh.
This wine has too much extraction to allow the fruit to develop. It will soften out, although not enough. It is an 80% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Sauvignon blend.
A southern yet herbal-feeling wine, this is ripe-maybe overripe-and missing real structure or fruitiness.
This wine's fruit is overripe, which spoils the structure that has been built around it.
This wine is all wood, with no promise of fruit.
While there is plenty of wood here (12 months in new barrels), the raisin character of the 60% Merlot and 40% Cabernet Sauvignon gives it a curious, dried-fruit flavor.
All dry tannin and bramble aromas, this wine is a tough proposition. François Maurin and son Raphael handle the organic vineyards and wine fermented in stainless steel.
A hard, very firm, lean wine, showing structure and tannins but little in the way of substance. Old-style winemaking produces an old style wine.
Already showing signs of aging, this is hard, dry and tough. Not much pleasure there.

The nose features some plum and faint cedar aromas, but not a lot of intensity; the light black-cherry and cedar flavors incorporate some earthy nuances on the finish. Light and correct, but where's the beef?

Weak cherry and cassis aromas are followed by dilute raspberry flavors. The finish is tangy and borderline thin, while the overall impression is sharp and tart. Despite all that it tastes fresh, not tired. Kosher.
Mushroom and plum aromas followed by coffee and black plum flavors. Hot, heavy and over the top.
This very ripe wine tastes of supermature grapes; it' s soft and formless.
Lean and rather dry, this has old wood and lean fruit flavors.

The problem with this wine is the wood. There is too much of it, and the toasting is too high, giving a burnt character to the wine. For a 2005, this should be better integrated, and is likely to just dry out.
Earthy, with little fruit. The flavors are thin and much like strawberry infused tea. Acidic and dry. Barely acceptable.

Remember that old TV commercial asking, "Where's the beef?" You can apply that here. It smells fresh enough, and there's cranberry-styled tart fruit backed up by oak. But it's way short on soul and stuffing. No need to hold this; drink it now for what fruit there is. Made from 75% Merlot.
Husky and muddled, with less than precise plum and berry flavors. The flavor profile doesn't sing and the finish is lean, drying and even a touch bitter at its culmination.
Green and underripe, with tobacco and rhubarb aromas. The flavors are too weedy and burnt for the wine to merit higher, and that's despite a perfectly good mouthfeel. Kosher.
Horsey and heavy in the nose, with some cinnamon sweetness. The fruit is big and overstuffed, like plum pie. There's also a burnt flavor and potent acidity.
